title: Home
text:
Welcome to my Warmup Website! It serves an example site for myself for CSC 324 at Georgetown College, as a warm up building your own website using the Quarto framework.
You can read a bit about me here.
To learn more about Quarto websites visit https://quarto.org/docs/websites.

title: My Additions to my Website:
My Additions to my Website:
My Additions to my Website:
My Additions to my Website:
text:
This calender is based on the Georgetown College’s csv file that can be aquired on their website. The code was all done in R script as well.

if(!require(toastui)) install.packages("toastui",repos = "http://cran.us.r-project.org")
library(tidyverse)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(purrr)
library(devtools)
library(toastui)

gc_events <- read_csv("assets/gcCalender.csv")

all_day_events <- gc_events %>% 
                    filter(`All day event` == TRUE)
# a filter of all the day(s) events to filter by
all_day_events <- all_day_events %>% 
                    mutate(`Start Date` = dmy(`Start Date`),
                           startYear = year(`Start Date`),
                           startDay = day(`Start Date`),
                           startMonth = month(`Start Date`),
                           
                           `End Date` = dmy(`End Date`),
                           endYear = year(`End Date`),
                           endDay = day(`End Date`),
                           endMonth = month(`End Date`)) %>% 
                    arrange(desc(Subject))
# marks all the events
mark_all_ad_events <- function(data = gc_events){
  val <- 0
  mark <- 0
  num <- 0
  i <- 0
  all_day_events <- gc_events %>% 
                      mutate(Subject = str_replace_all(Subject, "\\\x94 | \\?", ""),#replaces bad symbols
                             title = str_replace_all(Subject, "\\\x94 | \\?", ""),
                            `Start Date` = dmy(`Start Date`),
                             startYear = year(`Start Date`),
                             startDay = day(`Start Date`),
                             startMonth = month(`Start Date`),
                             
                             `End Date` = dmy(`End Date`),
                             endYear = year(`End Date`),
                             endDay = day(`End Date`),
                             endMonth = month(`End Date`)) %>% 
                      arrange(desc(Subject))
  
  titles <- all_day_events$Subject
  endDate_allDayEvent <- all_day_events$`End Date`

  #Checks if the events coming after one another are related and if they are to mark them with a number
  for (i in 1:(length(endDate_allDayEvent))) {
    title1 <- titles[i]
    title2 <- titles[i+1]
    
    date1 <- ymd(endDate_allDayEvent[i])
    date2 <- ymd(endDate_allDayEvent[i+1])
      num <- 0 + i
      if (all_day_events$`All day event`[i] == TRUE & all_day_events$`All day event`[i+1] == TRUE & title1 == title2 & all_day_events$startYear[i] == all_day_events$startYear[i+1] & all_day_events$startMonth[i] == all_day_events$startMonth[i+1] & all_day_events$endDay[num]+1 == all_day_events$startDay[num+1] & is.na(all_day_events$startDay[num+1]) != TRUE){
        num <- i + 0
        val[num] <- mark
      }else{
        val[i] <- mark
        mark  = mark + 1
        }
  }
  all_day_events$value <- val
  
  #shorten all the groups
  all_day_events <- all_day_events %>% 
                        group_by(title, value) %>% 
                        summarise(`Start Date`= min(`Start Date`),
                        `End Date`= max(`End Date`),
                        `Start Time`= first(na.omit(`Start Time` )),
                        `End Time`= first(na.omit(`End Time`)),
                        
                        Street = first(na.omit(Street)),
                        City = first(na.omit(City)),
                        state_prov = first(na.omit(`State or Province`)),
                        zip_postal = first(na.omit(`Zip or Postal Code`)),
                        Country = first(na.omit(Country)),
                        location = first(na.omit(Location)),
                        
                        body = first(na.omit(Description)),
                        Categories = first(na.omit(Categories)),
                        isAllday = first(na.omit(`All day event`)))
  
  # fixes strings so that they can have proper urls
  all_day_events <- all_day_events %>% mutate(newloc = paste0(na.omit(c("<a href=\"", "https://maps.google.com.br/?q=", first(Street), ", ", first(City), ", ", first(state_prov), " ", first(zip_postal), ", ", first(Country), "\" >", first(location), "</a>")), collapse = ""),
                               newloc = str_replace_all(newloc , pattern = "<a href=\"https:\\/\\/maps.google.com.br\\/\\?q=, ,  , \" ><\\/a>", replacement = ""),
                               newloc = str_replace_all(newloc, pattern = ", ,  , ", replacement = paste0(c("Georgetown College, ", first(location)), collapse = "")),
                               location = newloc,
                               category = case_when(isAllday == "TRUE" ~ "allday",
                                                    .default = "time")) 
  
  return(all_day_events)
}

# a way to hold on to the marked events
all_day_events <- mark_all_ad_events()

# the data gets mutated into a function with variables that the calander() command can read
gc_cal_data <- function(){
 all_day_events %>% 
      mutate(
        title = str_replace_all(title, "\\\x94 | \\?", "")) %>% 
         unite(start, c(`Start Date`, `Start Time`), sep = " ", remove = TRUE) %>% 
         unite(end, c(`End Date`, `End Time`), sep = " ", remove = TRUE) %>% 
         mutate(start = ymd_hms(start, tz = "UTC"),
                start = format(start, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S"),
                end = ymd_hms(end, tz = ""),
                end = format(end, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S")) %>% 
     mutate(is_holiday = case_when(TRUE == str_detect(title, "[Hh]oliday") ~ "yes",
                                 FALSE == str_detect(title, "[Hh]oliday") ~ "no"),
           id = case_when(is_holiday == "yes" ~ 1,
                          is_holiday == "no" ~ case_when(Categories == "Art" ~ 3,
                                                         Categories == "Academics" ~ 2,
                                                         Categories == "Equine Scholars" ~ 4,
                                                         Categories == "Nexus" ~ 5,
                                                         Categories == "Activities Council" ~ 5,
                                                         .default = 4)
                          ),
           calendarId = id) %>% 
    select(title, start, end, calendarId, id, body, location) 
}

# a function made to hold all the properties for the calender so it is able to be better understood by the cal_props() command
cal_gc_props <- function() {
  
  props <- list(
    list(
      id = "1",
      name = "Holidays & Closing",
      color = "#000",
      backgroundColor = "lightgray",
      borderColor = "gray"
    ),
    list(
      id = "2",
      name = "Academics",
      color = "#000",
      backgroundColor = "#FFD700",
      borderColor = "goldenrod3"
    ),
    list(
      id = "3",
      name = "Art",
      color = "#000",
      backgroundColor = "#AA336A",
      borderColor = "#702963"
    ),
    list(
      id = "4",
      name = "Equine Scholars",
      color = "#000",
      backgroundColor = "#05CDCD",
      borderColor = "#3b7cc6"
    ),
    list(
      id = "5",
      name = "Nexus",
      color = "#000",
      backgroundColor = "#EE0200",
      borderColor = "firebrick"
    ),
    list(
      id = "5",
      name = "Activites Council",
      color = "#000",
      backgroundColor = "#FF9902",
      borderColor = "darkorange3"
    ),
    list(
      id = "6",
      name = "Alumni",
      color = "#000",
      backgroundColor = "#EE82EE",
      borderColor = "darkorchid2"
    )
  )
  do.call("rbind", lapply(props, as.data.frame))
}

#displays the calander in a month format when all of the code finishes
calendar(gc_cal_data(), navigation = TRUE, isReadOnly = TRUE, useDetailPopup = TRUE, useCreationPopup = FALSE) %>%
  cal_props(cal_gc_props())






Important



DISCLAMER: Part of it is broken due to the automatic resizing issue from the toastui calender.js file.

title: Post about my Cat Jinx
text:
She was actually an abandoned kitten outside of the dorm; I was living in. She wasn’t heavy at all and was super skinny. She was in a box with a wet towel on her and a bowl of milk and bread. Jinx was supper lovable though, she loved on me when I approched the side door. She didn’t show any signs of being “spicy”.
She did have fleas at that time though. So I had to take her into the showers and give her a bath with dawn dishsoap which she did not like. And then I had to drive to Dollar General on my scooter and grab some flea and tick prevetion as well as a thin comb to get the rest off.
I then had to take her off of the campus and my grandmother then took care of her for while as I got ESA regestration for her.

title: Post about my Cat Jinx
text:
She was actually an abandoned kitten outside of the dorm; I was living in. She wasn’t heavy at all and was super skinny. She was in a box with a wet towel on her and a bowl of milk and bread. Jinx was supper lovable though, she loved on me when I approched the side door. She didn’t show any signs of being “spicy”.
She did have fleas at that time though. So I had to take her into the showers and give her a bath with dawn dishsoap which she did not like. And then I had to drive to Dollar General on my scooter and grab some flea and tick prevetion as well as a thin comb to get the rest off.
I then had to take her off of the campus and my grandmother then took care of her for while as I got ESA regestration for her.

title: Post about my Cat Jinx
text:
ESA Regestration:
Her ESA registaration was not easy but she did alot to help me emotionally. And I was also wanting an ESA as well. She had to get all her shots and had to have her collar and tags. It took awhile for all of it to come in and get done but It took long enough to get it all done for her. She stayed at my grandmother’s until it all went through. I think she stayed there for about 7 weeks in total as we waited for the conformation about her ESA status.

Going to the Vet:
First was going to the vet though. At the vet she got her annual shots and The vet also informed me that she was ~5 months at the time. I couldn’t belive it especially sense she weighed only ~4lbs at the time. She did really well at the vet other than the interation where she hissed at a dog.
They told me she had not been spayed as well so we had to go get her spayed soon. I thought it was going to be too much, but my roommate was a great help as they told me, “The Humane Society gives out flyers that will allow her to get spayed for cheeper.” So that day I went down and got a spay voucher and even got her microchiped for ~$37 usd. That helped so much.
I had to wait a long time for the Humane Society to make the appointment for me. But, the time they made it for was for Novmber 22 at 8:00am. The start of my Thanksgiving break. So she got spayed before Thanksgiving. I don’t think that is something to be thankful about though.

title: Kant and Lying to the Drunk Friend Senario
text: Christara Laing Dr. Shelly Johnson Ethics September 1, 2023

title: Kant and Lying to the Drunk Friend Senario
section: Kant and Lying to the Drunk Friend Scenario
text:
Kant and Lying to the Drunk Friend Scenario

Kant, a deontological moral philosopher, argues that the ground of morality is duty and obeying the categorical imperative (Kant 327). This imperative tells us that we should only act on the maxim we could will to be universal law (327). Another way of staying the categorical imperative is to say that we should treat people as an end in themselves and not just a means to our end (Kant 333). We can use Kant’s categorical imperative to help us understand the moral thing to do in situations like the Lying to the Drunk Friend Scenario. Kant would argue that the person in the Lying to the Drunk Friend Scenario (LDFS) is immoral but only due to the lie.
To understand why Kant would argue this, we must understand his moral theory. Firstly, morality isn’t grounded in empirical matters because morals are based on a priori reason and must be able to be applied universally to everyone and every situation. A priori reason is the knowledge we know from just reason alone (Kant 321-322). This a priori reason can also be used to understand the categorical imperative. The categorical imperative is the action is an end-in-itself (334). The categorical imperative tells us to only act on the maxim that we could will to be universal law (336). The categorical imperative can also be proven by the universality principle (“Kant & Categorical Imperatives: Crash Course Philosophy #35” 00:3:00–00:3:25). To quote Kant, “Act only according to that maxim which you can at the same time will that it should become a universal law without contradiction (qtd. in “Kant & Categorical Imperatives: Crash Course Philosophy #35” 00:3:00–00:3:25).” Dr. Johnson points out about Kant, “when we act morally, we have autonomy of the will– The will is a law unto itself (Kant 342)(Kant, Part #3 7)” . Autonomy through this quote is being able to act upon yourself through your own reasoning, without anything else, forcing you or forcing a law on you. If someone were to force a law on you or outside of you, then it’s heteronomy (Kant 342).
With all these things being said about Kant’s theory then what would Kant about the LDFS. The LDFS presents a scenario where you are given a gun by your friend. After a while your friend comes back, drunk, and asks you to hand him the gun; as he wants to kill another friend, he had a fight with. Kant would say in this situation you could not lie. As the maximum of lying is unable to be universalized. Which intern goes against Kants theory of universality.
A specific example that Kant uses about lying is (Kant & Categorical Imperatives: Crash Course Philosophy #35 00:5:01- 00:10:27) . If Elvira lies to the killer about where Tony is, Tony could be around the corner at the same time the killer decides to leave. This would have her responsible for Tony’s death. If she told the truth, then only the murderer would’ve been responsible for the deaths that occurred. The reason is she cannot control what the murderer does. She can only control what she does in the situation.
But if you give your friend the gun, then that Maxim would be giving your friend a gun. Which would allow them to murder someone meaning that guilt would be on you. So can’t would probably say in the situation that the best thing to do would be to not lie, but tell your friend, I am not giving you the gun because you’re drunk and also no matter what don’t give your friend the gun.

title: Kant and Lying to the Drunk Friend Senario
text:
Works Cited:
“Kant & Categorical Imperatives: Crash Course Philosophy #35.” Www.youtube.com, www.youtube.com/watch?v=8bIys6JoEDw&t=371s. Accessed 18 Sept. 2023.
Dr. Johnson, Shelly. “Kant, Part #3.pptx.” Kant, Part #3.pptx, 2003, georgetowncollege.instructure.com/courses/5574/files/1033310?module_item_id=276642. Accessed 19 Sept. 2023.
Kant, Immanuel. “Groundwork for the Metaphysics of Morals.” Ethics, by Steven Cahn and Peter Markie, 198 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10016, United States of America, Oxford University Press, 2019, pp. 320–336.

title: About Me:
text: I am a Kentucky born citizen, to be exact I born in Paris, Kentucky. From an early age I have always been intrested in coding. This is because my grandpa, worked with robots and helped fix their coding for NSG. I also was intrested in it because I played a lot of indie horror games. And I got to watch those games be coded up for others to play. I also love hiding secrets.

title: About Me:
text:
Studies:
I went to Highschool in Paris at Bourbon County High School. In BCHS I took a multitude of classes for computer science. I learned how to code for/in HTML, CSS, and a “simplified” verson of Python.
Now that I am in college at Georgetown College. I am taking a classes that has helped me learn: R, Javascript, and qurto.

Life At Georgetown:
My life at Georgetown has been pretty good as well. I have done more studies with diffrent programing languages, print-making, drawing, and general programing.
